 Staff Appraisal Report I 1. JUNIOR SECONDARY EDUCATION ISSUES IN FIVE SUMATRA PROVINCES: DI ACEH, WEST SUMATRA, JAMBI, SOUTH SUMATRA, AND LAMPUNG A. BACKGROUND 1.1 Over the last 25 years, the Government of Indonesia has demonstrated a strong commitment to education and as a result, the country has made impressive gains. The Government led a substantial school building program and enrollment drive in the 1970s (SD INPRES) sharply increasing primary school enrollment. The gross enrollment rate stood at 75 percent in the early 1970s but had increased to about 90 percent by the end of that decade. Since the mid-1980s, gross enrollment rates have exceeded 100 percent. The effort is not complete because of quality concerns and the need to increase retention rates, but the achievements at the primary level have been substantial in this diverse and far-flung archipelago. 1.2 The Government of Indonesia (GOI) is looking to future needs, and has reiterated its commitment to a proactive program in the future with expansion of junior secondary education as a priority. While maintaining its commitment to primary education, the Government is aiming for universal basic education (years 1-9) coverage, to meet the human resource requirements for transforming the economy from one based on natural resources to one based more on industry and technology. 1.3 The decision to expand junior secondary education participation as rapidly as feasible is justified for several reasons. First, expansion appears to be a precondition for the rapid growth of the Indonesian economy in the medium term. Recent research on the development of East Asian economies indicates that with the achievement of near universal primary education, secondary (junior and senior) education has had a strong impact on economic growth. Secondary education plays the role of providing educated entrants to the labor force, enhancing the trainability of workers, and providing qualified inputs into higher levels of education. 1.4 In this regard, the Indonesian economy and labor market is in the midst of a structural transformation. Since 1990, there has been a marked slow-down in employment creation in agriculture and an acceleration in the rate of growth of job creation in manufacturing, construction, transport and communication. After a period of wage stagnation in the 1980s, there are strong indications of rising real wage rates throughout the country and an absolute decline in agricultural employment. If sustained nationally for a decade or so, these trends imply the absorption of remaining pockets of surplus labor, and as happened in other NICs, the transformation from an agrarian economy to one relying on the education and productivity of its workers. Social rates of return to education computed for 1986-92 indicate that returns to junior secondary education are the highest among the education subsectors. 1.5 The second justification for significant Government attention to junior secondary education is that the number of school places is still limited relative to demand, despite
 2 Sumatra Junior Secondary Education Project substantial outlays by parents and a significant private sector response. This inadequacy is evident from continued strong demand for generally more costly and often lower quality private education, large numbers of unsuccessful applicants to schools, the prevalence of double shifts and large classes in schools, and the use of libraries and laboratories for classroom teaching. 1.6 A third rationale for Government intervention is to assist in removing barriers of cost and isolation that keep many of the rural poor out of school. In rural Sumatra, for example, total expenditure per junior secondary student is equivalent to approximately 86 percent of per capita expenditure in households of the lowest quintile. Junior secondary education is therefore beyond the reach of many of the poor and near poor. The opportunity costs of keeping children in school exacerbate the problem. Expansion of junior secondary education, especially in remote rural and fast growing areas with low enrollment rates will be of direct benefit to the poor, especially girls who are sometimes disadvantaged in these areas. 1.7 A fourth rationale relates to likely externalities associated with investments in secondary education. Research from other countries has pointed to externalities such as reduced fertility and child mortality and improved nutritional status that correlate with female secondary education. For Indonesia, survey results indicate that a mother's education is an important determinant of prenatal care utilization: more than 90 percent of women with junior secondary education use prenatal care, in contrast to only 75 percent of women with some primary education. Furthermore, analysis of nutritional status in Indonesia finds a strong effect of maternal education on children's nutritional status: for women with between zero and five years of education, an additional year of education has no impact on the child's nutritional status, while, among women with six to twelve years of education (or more), an additional year of education improves nutritional status significantly. 1.8 The role of the Government would therefore be to (a) help expand the number of school places through a combination of direct investment and measures to stimulate further private sector/community participation in the provision of school places; (b) improve the teaching - learning quality of the existing and new junior secondary schools; and (c) ensure that the poor are given increased opportunity to participate in the expansion process. Sector Financing Plan 1.9 Achieving universal nine-year basic education will require significant additional public resources to be directed to the education sector overall and to basic education in particular. Estimates of the total costs of the junior secondary expansion program come to approximately $7.6 billion to be implemented over a 15-year period. The cost estimates assume that the private sector will maintain its share of total enrollment of about 40 percent. Additional financing of an average $120 million during the next ten years of expansion (assuming 6 percent p.a. growth of the budget) would be required, implying that the budgetary allocation to junior secondary education would need to increase from the current 13 percent of the education budget to approximately 16 percent in the next few years. Overall, Indonesia would need to increase its allocation to education as a proportion of GDP by approximately 0.2 percent (this does not take into account, however, increases in other education subsectors, which may equally be required).
 StaffAppraisal Report 3 1.10 Government has demonstrated its commitment to expansion of junior secondary education through increases in its education investments. In its most recent budget allocations (1996/97) the education sector budget was increased by 20 percent, one of the highest increases amongst all sectors. The budget for junior secondary education saw a 24 percent rise over last year's budget allocation. GOI is also requesting help from donors, including the World Bank, to close the financing gap. Structure of the Education System 1.11 The Indonesian education system consists of a six-year primary school cycle, junior and senior secondary school cycles of three years each, and a postsecondary system ranging from one to six years. Primary education is largely the domain of Government: nearly five out of six pupils are enrolled in public schools. Private schooling plays a much greater role in secondary education. Private schools account for 41 percent of enrollment in junior secondary education and 54 percent in senior secondary. Junior secondary education is provided through 8,712 public (46 percent) and 10,279 private (54 percent) general junior secondary schools (SMP). The Ministry of Religious Affairs (MORA) administers the 582 public and 7,547 private madrasah tsanawiyah muslim schools (MTs) at the junior secondary level. At the senior secondary level, 3,241 public and 10,380 private schools enroll a total of 4.2 million students, for a gross enrollment rate of 34 percent. 1.12 When a private junior secondary school is established, it is "registered" and evaluated after graduating its first students. Private schools can advance in accreditation from"registered" to "recognized" and finally to the status of "equivalent" to public schools. Most equivalent schools are owned and operated by religious organizations. Registered and recognized schools are in general owned and operated by teachers' associations and other nonprofit organizations (yayasans), although some are owned by religious organizations or small communities. Most registered schools are owned and operated by small rural communities that do not have a public school nearby. Almost invariably, schools established by communities aspire to complete Government takeover, while private yayasans often prefer partial Government support so they can maintain control. Schools established by teachers' associations often use public school facilities after hours and employ public school teachers as instructors. B. SECTOR ISSUES AND NATIONAL INITIATIVES 1.13 Despite high gross enrollment rates, about 22 percent of primary school pupils, especially in the more difficult remote areas, do not complete the full six years of education. Universal nine-year education, however, depends on improving the efficiency of the primary system and producing an expanded pool of candidates for junior secondary school. The Government has started addressing this issue through a series of initiatives, including the Primary Education Quality Improvement Project (Ln. 3448-lND) which is piloting measures for improving education quality. 1.14 In spite of the constraints to access and quality at the junior secondary level, Indonesia has made great strides in gender equality in both primary and junior secondary education. Only slightly fewer girls than boys are enrolled in school at the national level. Girls also have lower
 4 Sumatra Junior Secondary Education Project drop-out and repeater rates than boys and are often higher achievers. However, rural conditions similar to those which present obstacles to the development of junior secondary education also adversely affect the participation of girls. When schools are located a long way from homes, parents are less willing to let their daughters commute long distances or to undertake the costly expenditures of relocation to urban areas. 1.15 In addition to access and quality, all provinces face new and existing management challenges as a result of the deconcentration of tasks from the center to the provinces, a process this project will support. For historical and political reasons, public administration in Indonesia has been highly centralized and decision making is tightly controlled by central Government in Jakarta. The center has traditionally set objectives for education expansion and development, with few inputs from the provinces. However, the differences of local conditions in each province and district, accentuated by the great distances of the outer islands from the administrative center, make it increasingly difficult for central administration to devise and implement satisfactory solutions to local problems. Although Jakarta will retain a significant role in providing policy guidelines and promoting regional equity and overall economic development, the Government has decided gradually to devolve authority to the provinces and districts. This devolution will result in a deconcentration of the functions of the MOEC to provincial (Kanwil) and district (Kandep/Kanin) education offices. Initiatives Related to Access 1.16 GOI is aware of these problems and a number of initiatives have been put in place to address them. To improve access, the policy of establishing a minimum size of nine classrooms for Government schools, which has prevented opening schools in small communities, is being changed to make it easier for schools with fewer classrooms to be built. 1.17 Private schools supported by local communities, private educational foundations and religious groups account for about 40 percent of total enrollment at the junior secondary level. GO! supports these schools through a variety of measures, including provision of teachers, but they are generally of lower quality and cost more to parents. The low quality in these schools is explained by poor quality teachers and scarcity of educational materials. Unit costs of operations in these schools is, however, lower than in public schools. Current and proposed GOI support for private education would help maintain or increase its share of enrollment and improve quality. In the more southern provinces of Sumatra (Jambi, South Sumatra and Lampung), private schools are responsible for 30-50% of enrollment; in Aceh and West Sumatra, however, only for about 17%. 1.18 In some sparsely populated areas, regular schools still will be far away for most students. The SMP Terbuka ("open SMP") programs have been established to meet the needs of students who cannot attend regular schools because of distance or high direct and opportunity costs. These are non-fee-paying schools, and students attend afternoon classes one or more times a week, usually at a junior secondary school, supplemented by tutorials in their villages. 1.19 To assist rural families who cannot afford to pay for education, GOI has established a scholarship program for children of low economic background and satisfactory academic achievement. This program covers all costs related to junior secondary education; within the
 StaffAppraisal Report 5 eligible group, priority is given to children from remote areas, orphans, and girls. GOI plans to expand this program, to improve its effectiveness. Initiatives Related to Quality 1.20 Various initiatives have also been introduced to improve the quality of junior secondary education, including efforts to bring good teachers to underserved areas. Although there is an excess number of teachers in the aggregate, there is an unequal distribution of teachers between urban and rural areas within provinces because most rural teaching positions are considered undesirable. To address this issue of shortages of (particularly core subject) teachers in rural and remote areas, "contract teachers" are being proposed in rural schools in core academic areas. Some rural communities have also provided their teachers with dormitories. In addition, the Government is already providing some financial compensation for service in hardship areas. Over the longer term, local recruitment is one practice that will help to keep teachers in rural areas. 1.21 Developed from an initiative taken by the subject teacher quality improvement forum (MGMP), an in-service teacher training program called PKG was introduced in 1983 to improve the subject-matter knowledge and skills of teachers. This program was highly successful in improving the pedagogical skills of teachers in the selected subject areas and created a positive attitude among teachers where it was provided. There were however some serious shortcomings of the program. The subject-matter knowledge of teachers was not fully addressed, development of skills in identifying learning difficulties was neglected, and teachers in rural areas could not be covered because of high costs and logistical difficulties. Training was provided every weekend followed by classroom visits, and trainees were supposed to develop their own materials. Some of the rural teachers who could be reached could not take full advantage of the program because of weak qualifications. Revitalization of content and decentralization of the PKG and MGMP system to the district level and the systematic involvement of regional MOEC staff, including supervisors and principals in the training program, would help address this issue. C. JUNIOR SECONDARY EDUCATION IN THE SUMATRA PROVINCES General Description of Project Provinces 1.22 The Sumatra Junior Secondary Education Project covers five of the country's 27 provinces: (a) DI Aceh, (b) West Sumatra, (c) Jambi, (d) South Sumatra, and (e) Lampung. Other recently approved projects are the East Java and NTT Junior Secondary Education Project and the Central Indonesia Junior Secondary Education Project. The project provinces face challenges in the provision of junior secondary education that are common to all provinces in Indonesia, though not to the same extent. These challenges are (a) to expand equitable access to junior secondary education; (b) to improve the quality of education throughout the provinces; and (c) to make education management more efficient as the provinces assume increased responsibility. Access is restricted mainly by the lack of places; high direct and opportunity costs; and great distances and limited transportation networks in some provinces. In some instances, parents in very remote or difficult areas do not express interest in junior secondary education because they think it is beyond their reach. The most important factors affecting
 6 Sumatra Junior Secondary Education Project quality and internal efficiency are: teacher knowledge and skills; the availability of textbooks, teaching materials, and equipment; the curriculum; pedagogical supervision; the flexibility of the school calendar; school management; and examinations and educational assessment. With regard to primary and junior secondary education, these provinces exhibit the following similar characteristics (See Table 1.2): In primary schools: * A gross enrollment rate as high or higher than the national average. * A repetition rate higher than the national average and a lower than average retention rate. In junior secondary schools: * Gross enrollment rates lower than the national average for the three southern provinces (Jambi, South Sumatra and Lampung), but higher for Aceh and West Sumatra. * Similarly, lower transition rates from primary schools for the same three provinces vs. higher ones for the last two. * Wide differences between provinces in drop-out and repetition rates. Generally, the education programs in these provinces face the following challenges: (a) All provinces have in varying degrees remote-access and sparsely populated areas in mountainous regions, swamp areas and forested islands, making it difficult to provide access widely through regular schools. Alternatives, such as SMP Terbuka, are therefore appropriate. (b) The existence of substantial remote and rural areas has resulted in a particularly severe problem of imbalance in teacher distribution, with rural schools lacking teachers in all provinces. (c) The three southern provinces, Jambi, South Sumatra and Lampung, are subjected to heavy and continuous in-migration from Java, both planned and spontaneous. Education administrators need to be especially skilled in school expansion planning under these conditions. (d) For junior secondary education, enrollments and other indicators are generally below the national averages, although not by much, perhaps reflecting the more difficult geographic conditions. These provinces, therefore, will need to make a greater effort in reaching the targets. DI ACEH 1.26 DI Aceh is located on the northern tip of the island of Sumatra and facing northern Malaysia. From the perspective of the project, what distinguishes this province is:

Distinguishing characteristics of this province are: * Out-migration of 1.78 per thousand in 1980-90, with population density over the 1980-90 period increasing by less than the country average, and a population growth rate, at 1.6% p.a. lower than the country average. * Some 33% of the labor force is educated at junior secondary school level and above, compared with only 27% for the country as a whole. Similarly, illiteracy rates are among the lowest in the country, at 8% versus 14% for Indonesia. * A diverse physical environment of the province and the presence of a large island population resulting in uneven enrollment levels. * A high primary school repetition rate at 10%, compared with the country average of 7.6%, perhaps due to children absenteeism in this mountainous province. * A primary-junior secondary school transition rate of 71% compared with 67% nationally, with a high enrollment rate of 67% versus 58%.

GOVERNMENT STRATEGY 2.1 As part of the Repelita VI (1994/99) program, the Government set the important goal of extending access to high quality junior secondary education. This objective is integral to the goal of attaining universal coverage of nine-years of basic education by the end of Repelita VII (2004/05). To support this goal, the Government has adopted several policy measures and strategies: (a) it plans to provide additional resources to basic education; (b) it has abolished junior secondary school fees; (c) it is providing free textbooks for all primary and junior secondary schoolchildren; (d) it is supporting private junior secondary schools with public teachers and other inputs to maintain and even increase their significant enrollment participation at this school level; (e) it continues to upgrade teachers' skills for both public and private schools through in-service programs; (f) it has started the construction or development of regular or alternative schools in rural and remote villages; (g) it has phased out all diploma courses for the preservice education of secondary school teachers (junior and senior) so all new teachers at that level now need to have an SI (undergraduate degree); (h) it is upgrading existing junior secondary school teachers to D-III (three-year post-secondary diploma); and (i) it is extending subsidies (scholarships) to capable but poor students to begin or continue junior secondary education. B. LESSONS LEARNED 2.2 Integration of the following lessons from previous Bank projects would help build on the exceptional performance of the Bank in the education sector in Indonesia. All the 21 previous projects have been judged satisfactory by OED, and they have set the stage for the more challenging tasks in this sector. OED Document, No. 9752, Indonesian Education and the World Bank: an Assessment of Two Decades of Lending, 1991: a) found that each of the previous projects was successfully implemented; b) concluded that Bank support in education projects was timely and gave valuable encouragement to the Government; and c) pointed out that the projects were successes and achieved important goals, but also indicated shortcomings in the quality of education and fragmented management and coordination --issues being addressed by the present project. 2.3 OED Report. The 1991 report has several conclusions and recommendations that are relevant for this project: Issue: Institution building is basic to the long-term goal of increasing the self-sufficiency of the Indonesian education system (p. 58). Project response: Increased emphasis on institution building and self-management at provincial and district levels.
 Staff Appraisal Report 13 Issue: Projects must be discussed within the framework of the policy dialogue (p. 65). Project response: Regular discussions between MOEC and the Bank on development priorities and the role of the Bank related to other donors are instrumental in determining agenda for Bank lending. Issue: Despite explicit goals, projects have not always achieved equitable distribution of project benefits to the poor (p. 68). Project response: Several project interventions are specifically targeted to the poor: school construction in rural areas, SMP Terbuka and scholarship program. Issue: Previous projects (mainly national in scope) were often overly complex or underestimated absorption constraints and experience, resulting in unsatisfactory implementation (p. 70). Project response: The project has been designed with extensive participation from communities, existing schools, district and provincial MOEC staff. Issue: GOI should spend a greater amount of its budget on education, to achieve the necessary quality and institutional objectives (p. 78). Project response: Indonesia's education expenditures are 14 percent of total government budget; The 1996/97 budget shows an increase of 20 percent over last year, of which 72 percent is spent on basic education (primary and junior secondary). Issue: Despite its support from GOI and the Bank (p.79) role in providing educational opportunities, the private system has received limited support from GOI and the Bank (p. 79). Project response: GOI is now committed to ensuring that the involvement of the private sector in junior secondary education is maintained and strengthened. Recent projects have helped private schools improve their quality. 2.4 Lessons from completed and ongoing projects in secondary education. Other lessons have been drawn or confirmed by the General Operational Review of Secondary Education Projects by HDD. Implementation of the Indonesia Secondary Education Project (Ln. 2472- IND) and the ongoing Second Secondary Education and Management Project (Ln. 3158-lND) are particularly relevant in this respect. (a) Overall Project Design. The completed and ongoing secondary education projects have demonstrated that the expansion of secondary education should be addressed through a dual strategy of increasing school places and improving the quality of education. The proposed project would include both expansion and quality improvement objectives, to ensure continuing demand for education and to improve repetition and drop-out rates. (b) Flexibility in the Design of Components. Attempts to impose standard solutions to the variety of conditions in Indonesia (as in all large countries) have not been successful, and GOI is working to correct this situation, the policy of limiting the size of government schools to a minimum of nine classrooms has been reviewed, to allow government schools to be established in communities

Local communities contribute significantly to the development of education in their areas. Stakeholders and clients are also well placed to evaluate project outcomes. They know when children are learning and how investments in schools are being used. Stakeholder involvement (which was emphasized during the preparation process) is critical to fully measure project outcomes, to understand how a project is unfolding and to help develop appropriate corrective measures when necessary. The project will promote and supplement the use of local resources for education by providing assistance in kind and incentives for both private and public education. C. BANK STRATEGY AND RATIONALE FOR INVOLVEMENT 2.5 This project, the third in a series of junior secondary education investments financed by the Bank, supports the Bank's 1995 Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Indonesia, which was presented to the Board on March 21, 1995 and updated on June 4, 1996. The CAS endorses Government's role towards establishing a regulatory framework and in supporting decentralization and participation. In addition, the CAS highlights the importance of continued emphasis on human resource development to promote economic growth, competitiveness, and structural transformation, and on a more selective, efficient use of public resources. The design of the proposed project is also consistent with the Bank's strategy of balanced assistance to the education sector, which includes on-going and proposed assistance for (a) improving the quality of primary education, including possible interventions in early childhood development; (b) expansion and quality improvement of lower-secondary education; (c) quality improvement of upper-secondary education; (d) selective interventions in higher education; and (e) an active policy dialogue designed to redefine and refocus the Government's role in the education sector. Before continuing with further projects in Basic Education in Indonesia, the Board and GOI will hold a joint seminar, to discuss future strategy and Bank involvement. 2.6 The Bank's comparative advantage in supporting junior secondary education is based on its long-standing and close working relationship with MOEC. The Bank has engaged in a comprehensive dialogue with MOEC that reaches far beyond this project itself, since it has helped to: (a) establish a solid conceptual and economic framework for the expansion and improvement of junior secondary education and basic education in Indonesia over the next 20 years; (b) identify the comparative advantages for the Bank's and other donors' role in the planned expansion and quality improvement process; and (c) strengthen the decentralizing trends toward sub-central levels, province-specific projects, and local ownership. As a result of this dialogue, the previous higlhly centralized, uniform approach to project design and implementation has been abandoned and has been replaced by an approach that will rest on provincially based projects. This approach recognizes the need to take into account specific provincial situations, including economic growth trends and prospects, the existing education needs, labor market conditions, private sector delivery capacity, levels of poverty, and geographic conditions. The Bank has also been an active partner in the discussions on the priorities governing basic education delivery, on the role of the private sector in secondary education and on the share of Government spending that should be allocated to basic education.

Based on the Bank's worldwide experience, GOI sought the Bank's advice on such issues as lower-cost alternatives for junior secondary education, how to improve quality and how to tailor the proposed increased access programs to local needs. The proposed project represents one in an overall program of Bank support for expansion and quality improvements in basic education. Currently, the Bank is starting two other secondary education projects (East Java/NTT Junior Secondary Education and Central Indonesia Junior Secondary Education) and the Government has requested that the Bank provide both financial and technical assistance for future projects. The junior secondary education development program is supported by other donors, including ADB and OECF. This project complements the assistance to basic education provided by several ongoing projects: (a) Second Secondary Education and Management Project. After initial problems, mainly due to the large national scope, the project was restructured to operate in five pilot provinces, with satisfactory results. The implementation experience from this project has provided the basis for the design of the current project. In addition, the Bank is now very familiar with the issues and the agencies involved in this subsector at the provincial level. (b) The Primary and Secondary School Teacher Development Projects. These two projects (Ln. 3496-IND and 3979-IND) address pre-service training of primary and secondary school teachers respectively. They complement the current project in the preparation and quality improvements of teachers and substantial coordination between pre-service and in-service training is achieved through the concurrent implementation of these projects. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 3.1 The project would assist the MOEC in achieving a greater number of junior secondary school graduates of better quality upon graduation. This would be pursued by: (a) expanding access to junior secondary education in a cost-effective and equitable way; (b) improving the quality of junior secondary education; and (c) strengthening the education management capacity at all levels. B. PERFORMANCE INDICATORS AND CRITICAL SUCCESS FACTORS 3.2 Project impact will be assessed using the following indicators (see Annex 10): (a) achievement of project enrollment targets by province (satisfactory if 75 percent achieved) in new junior secondary schools constructed under the project, by project completion date; (b) an increase in student examination scores for core subjects by at least 10 percent for each subject by the end of the project (on a score of I to 10, with current averages between 3.5 and 6); and (c) implementation of at least 80 percent of the annual work program as measured by the physical targets and budget spent each fiscal year for project and routine activities in each province. C. PROJECT DESCRIPTION Project Components 3.3 To meet the objectives of increasing access to junior secondary education, improving the quality of junior secondary education, and enhancing education management, activities related to the following components and subcomponents would be implemented selectively and in varying degrees in the public and private systems of the five project provinces. The total cost of the project is US$144.0 million, including contingencies. 3.4 Expand Access (estimated base costs of US$78.5 million). To improve access to junior secondary education, the project would (a) create a total of 53,520 student school places by building regular junior secondary schools with priority for underserved rural areas where female participation is also lowest; (b) gradually expand alternative equivalency programs by creating 27,600 places with greater quality inputs for those who cannot attend

See Annex 4 for more details on options for increasing access. During negotiations, the Government gave assurances that it will (i) select locations for construction in accordance with criteria agreed with the Bank and (ii) award scholarships in accordance with criteria acceptable to the Bank (See para 6.01 [a]). 3.5 New schools will be built only in rural areas, where no existing schools are yet available, either public or private. School location will be determined based on local planning, which will take into account existing SMP schools and the locations of the feeder SD schools. Six-classroom schools are preferred in these provinces, since once established and filled, they are less costly to run than the smaller 3-classroom schools, which require a larger number of teachers relative to the number of students. 3.6 Improve Quality (estimated base costs of US$35.2 million). To improve the quality of junior secondary education, the project would (a) strengthen school teachers' subject- matter knowledge and pedagogical skills, including identification of learning difficulties, through inservice and upgrading training programs, and support measures to bring teachers to rural areas; (b) enhance the learning environment by providing schools with tools for teaching and learning, including educational equipment and materials; science teaching aids; new teaching rooms; and library and reference books; and (c) provide contract teachers for rural areas. All public schools, including schools supported by MOEC and by MORA, will be included in the project. All private schools, subject to certain criteria, will also be eligible for quality improvement inputs. Criteria for private school inclusion are all schools with: (a) classroom size equal or greater than the provincial private school average; (b) own land and school buildings; and (c) at least half of teachers as regular, full-time teachers. These access and quality interventions would help increase access of girls in areas where gender disparities still exist. During negotiations, the Government gave assurances that it will employ contract teachers during the project, in the numbers and locations and with the criteria as agreed with the Bank (See para 6.01 [a]). 3.7 Strengthen Education Management (estimated base costs of US$5.1 million). To strengthen the management of the education system, the project would (a) train school principals and other administrators in managing schools and providing pedagogical support to teachers; and (b) develop managerial and data analysis capacity to allow provincial and district staff to effectively handle their increasing responsibilities for education planning and management. During negotiations, the Government gave assurances that it will carry out the management training in accordance with criteria acceptable to the Bank (See para 6.01 [a]). 3.8 Project Management (estimated base costs of US$7.3 million). The project would support the strengthening of institutional capacities as well as the operational costs of project management by the Kanwils and Kandeps. Coordination requirements by the MOEC Directorate of Secondary Education (Dikmenum) would be provided under the Central Indonesia Junior Secondary Education Project.

PROJECT ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 3.54 The economic analysis conducted for the project consisted of. (a) analysis of educational demand and the rationale for public investment in junior secondary education; (b) fiscal analysis; (c) review of alternatives; and (d) cost-benefit analysis. Details are provided in Annex 1. 3.55 There are both efficiency and equity grounds for additional public intervention in junior secondary education in Indonesia today. It is primarily the poor and near-poor (and mostly those in rural areas) who are not enrolling in school and whose participation declined in the late 1980s to early 1990s. One of the primary factors explaining the low demand is the high direct costs of education. A second factor is indirect (opportunity) costs which exacerbated the effect of high direct costs. Coupled with stagnant real wages in the I 980s and the effects of cuts in public expenditure on basic education in the mid-I 980s (school construction came to a virtual halt), these factors contributed to faltering demand. The past two years have seen the reversal of these trends as enrollment rates have risen significantly in all provinces. 3.56 Since investment in junior secondary education is desirable on both efficiency and equity grounds, the key questions for the Government are the budgetary implications of the expansion and how to expand the system. The budgetary implications of the expansion are sizable (8.7 billion; see Annex 1), but estimation shows that the policy is attainable if the economy continues to grow at the rate attained in recent decades, additional funds are made available to junior secondary including external borrowing, and the private sector retains its current significant share. 3.57 Assuming 6% per annum real growth of the budget, the project's incremental recurrent costs will take from 2 to 4% of the educational budgets, depending on the province, to support investments representing 22.4% of total requirements (See Table 3.1).

Increasing Places in Public Schools. To increase the opportunities for junior secondary education, building or expanding traditional junior secondary schools as well as developing the small SMP, or SMP Kecil, are the first options. Each of these options will-be appropriate and cost-effective only in certain circumstances and will be introduced when compatible with local conditions in each of the provinces, as determined by specific criteria drawn up by each province. Regular SMP and SMP Kecil. Standard building designs for regular SMPs call for 9, 18, or 27 classrooms. In densely populated areas, regular SMPs remain the obvious solution to increase access. However, schools of standard size are too large to serve rural areas with small, scattered populations, which nevertheless have sufficient cohort populations to justify a new small school. To increase access in these areas, the Government plans to use the SMP Kecil, which has fewer than nine classrooms. There would be fewer teachers than the usual requirement (at least five subject teachers for this type of schools). The main advantage of the SMP Kecil is that it would allow the services of traditional schools to be provided to underserved areas with small numbers of potential students. The SMP Terbuka program, now in operation for only the second year, is conceived as a major alternative for school-age children who fail to enter a regular public school because of financial difficulties in entering a public or private school, low grades in the end-of-level Ebtanas examinations, and/or lack of facilities in the area. Over the past twenty years the Indonesian government has provided two major kinds of teacher education activities for its junior secondary school (SMP) teachers, pre-service education and in-service education. In the 1 970s and 1 980s, when access to secondary education was expanding very rapidly, there were chronic shortages of secondary school teachers. Thus, various diploma programs were created to provide post-secondary pre-service teacher education opportunities for new teachers. For many years the government operated a special one-year training program (PGSMTP) for SMP teachers which provided D-1 certification; gradually preparation shifted to IKIPs and FKIPs which offered two year D-ll programs. By the end of the 1980s, as supply began to catch up with demand, all PGSMTP programs had been closed and D-11 programs were being phased out. By the early 1990s, all secondary school teachers, SMA and SMP, were expected to earn an SI university degree. At the same time, new elementary school teachers were required to obtain D-II certification and practicing teachers assisted in upgrading to the D-ll level. Under these conditions, it was considered necessary to provide D-III upgrading for SMP teachers. This has been a large task since a majority of teachers still have D-1 or D-I1 qualifications. (The proportion with below D-1I1 qualifications as of 1994/95 varied from 55% in West Sumatra to 95% in Jambi.) D-III upgrading is now well underway in Science, Math, and English; it has recently begun in Bahasa Indonesia; it has yet to begin in Social Studies. 2. Also, as a consequence of the policy requiring 9 years of basic education (SD + SMP), more SMPs are being opened in rural areas. Given the size of the catchment area in such areas, many of these SMPs are quite small, having perhaps one or two classes per grade. In such circumstances it is difficult to justify a full complement of teachers covering all subject areas. This means that many teachers have to teach in more than one subject area. Under the recently launched, Bank-supported Secondary School Teacher Education project many new SMP teachers will be prepared during pre- service teacher education to teach more than one subject. For those who have already been pressed into such service, special teacher certification programs are needed to help them become better prepared to teach subjects in which they have not been trained. 3. With respect to inservice of education, the country has succeeded over the past twenty years in developing an extensive group of secondary school teachers into teacher trainers both at the provincial and district levels. At the provincial level, instructors have been trained, many at the advanced graduate level (MA) to plan school-based teacher education efforts (originally called Pemantapan Kerja Guru or PGK, now usually referred to us Musyawara Guru Mata Pelajaran or MGMP), to train the local tutors for those programs (Guru Inti), and to manage special PKG programs (Model C) for teachers from remote area schools. Guru Inti (key teachers) have been trained and commissioned to provide in-service activities at the district and sometimes school cluster level. Whereas this program has provided invaluable human resources for school-based quality improvement activities, in recent years the program has become routinized and therefore less

It can be said that Indonesian junior secondary educators deliver a body of planned curricular content, but pay insufficient attention to what and how pupils are learning. Thus, in order to improve teachers' classroom effectiveness, changes in school-based teacher development activities are suggested in three areas: curriculum content, delivery mechanisms and training program management. The recommendations for the reform of the in-service teacher training component of the project are based on findings of the JGF-sponsored report, "Secondary Education in Indonesia: Strengthening Teacher Competency and Student Learning." doc.repnme: Indonesia - Sumatra Junior Secondary Education Project
doc.abstracts: The Sumatra Junior Secondary Education Project will assist the Ministry of Education and Culture (MOEC) in achieving a greater number of junior secondary school graduates of better quality upon graduation. This will be pursued by: 1) expanding access to junior secondary education in a cost-effective and equitable way; 2) improving the quality of junior secondary education; and 3) strengthening the education management capacity at all levels. To meet these objectives, the following components and subcomponents will be implemented selectively and in varying degrees in the public and private systems of the five project provinces: DI Aceh, West Sumatra, Jambi, South Sumatra, and Lampung. The first objective will involve: 1) creation of a total of 53,520 student school places; 2) gradual expansion of alternative equivalency programs; 3) student and teacher accommodations for public schools in rural and remote areas; and 4) financing of scholarships for 32,600 talented poor students with priority given to girls. The second objective will require: 1) strengthening of teachers' subject-matter knowledge and pedagogical skills; 2) enhancement of learning environment; and 3) provision of contract teachers for rural areas. The third objective will be achieved by: 1) training school principals and other administrators in managing schools and providing pedagogical support to teachers; and 2) developing managerial and data analysis capacity.
